There are two ways to approach a goal or deadline.  

You can start early and small or late and big.  

“Late and big” means doing it all at the last minute.  

This involves pulling an all-nighter and “making it happen.”  

“Early and small” means starting at the earliest moment possible.  

It requires minimal time investment.  

Often, just ten minutes invested two weeks before a deadline helps.  

This can save you from frantic scrambling at the last minute.  

Take a goal you have coming up.  

Ask yourself, “What is the minimal amount I could do right now to prepare?”  

One inspiring leader prepares big speeches six months in advance.  

He doesn’t prepare the entire speech; he just starts.  

If you have a big presentation coming up, open a file now.  

Spend four minutes writing down any ideas.  

Then close the file.  

No more than four minutes.  

Just start it.  

A colleague in New York uses a simple hack.  

Whenever she schedules a meeting, she takes fifteen seconds.  

She types the main objectives for the meeting.  

On the morning of the meeting, she prepares talking points.  

She can refer to these objectives.  

She doesn’t need to plan the whole agenda.  

Just a few seconds of early preparation pays off.
